schedule.topic: Course overview and goals, logistics, software, introduction to computing and to computers
Basic Python: primitive scalar object types, basic operators, variables and assignment, casting and conversions, syntactic and semantic errors, notion of functions
How to use the Spyder editor, experimenting with basic python concepts, code debugging, Autolab and Autograder
Notion of non-scalar data types, basic operations with string data type (length, indexing, slicing, replacing, finding), operator overloading, conversions, basic I/O (print(), input())
Boolean data types, logical operators, flow control using conditional constructs, indentation and scoping
Use of all primitive data types, program branching and decision-making using conditionals, basic I/O
Iteration: Repeated actions using while loops, use of counters, break statement, scope of variables
Iteration: Repeated actions using for loops, ranging over numbers and strings, nested loops and scoping
Flow control using while and for loops, variable scope
Functions for decomposition, abstraction, and reusability: definition, arguments, keyword arguments and default values, returning values, stack frames, local and global scoping
Special functions, modules, and import: main(), help() and docstrings, signals and exceptions, import statements, dot notation
Functions, testing and debugging with built-in tools, use and creation of imported modules (Numpy)

Non-scalar data types: tuples, mutability and lists, creating lists, retrieving and adding elements, slicing and cloning, operator overloading and concatenation, aliasing, list comprehension, methods available for lists
Sports Day
Operations on and manipulation of lists data types
All topics considered so far in the course
Non-scalar data types: lists to represent multi-dimensional data arrays, use of the Numpy module, applications in numeric linear algebra and image processing
Multi-dimensional data arrays, use of Numpy functionalities
Structured non-scalar data types: dictionaries, creating strong paired data, iterating over the items and over the keys, accessing items, adding and removing items
Regular expressions for searching for patterns in strings: ra module, character groups, quantifiers, extraction, position, finding multiple matches
Use of dictionaries and regular expressions for structuring and searching data
Spring Break
Spring Break
Spring Break
Reading and writing files: opening and closing files, error codes, paths, reading lines, writing formatted text
Files, programs, and user inputs: creating, deleting, and renaming files and folders, running programs, reading command line arguments
Using I/O from/to files and command line to manipulate bases of data
Object-oriented programming: abstract data types and classes, methods, instantiation, designing modular and reusable programs using abstract data types
Object-oriented programming: inheritance, encapsulation and information hiding, iterators
Designing code using object-oriented programming
Divide-and-conquer paradigm: divide-conquer-combine, from iteration to recursion, advantages and challenges, factorial and binary search examples
Divide-and-conquer paradigm: mergesort and quicksort examples, tower of Hanoi, memory and time requirements
Application of the divide-and-conquer paradigm, use of recursion
Efficiency of algorithms: notion of complexity, number of operations, worst case behavior, big O notation, basic examples of linear, log-linear, log, polynomial, exponential complexities
Efficiency of algorithms: complexity analysis of different algorithms for search and sorting tasks
Focus on the topics considered from the first assessment test up to now
Data visualization and animation using Matplotlib: overview, main functionalities, data plotting
Data visualization and animation using Matplotlib: complex data plots, basic animations
Use of Matplotlib for data visualization and animation
Simulation models: agent-based models, Cellular Automata for deterministic simulation of spatially distributed process
Simulation models: random number generation in a computer, notion of Monte Carlo techniques, Genetic Algorithms for solving complex optimization problems
Implementing simulation models in application scenarios of interest
Combinatorial models: knapsack optimization problems, practical applications, greedy approaches, dynamic programming approach, complexity
Combinatorial models: graph optimization problems, finding the shortest path, finding the min-cut, practical applications, complexity
FINAL EXAM (TBD)
